reviewText:
A masterpiece, an absalute treat to play with very little to complain about!

Good:
- A unique mechanic/gimic that is very VERY well implimented, makes a very personal feeling world with very pretty colours and therefore making dark confusing world into a bight vivid one.
- A well designed death system, I'm not quite sure what to call this but the way the developers made it so that dyingis not always bad, it works so that dying now just a way to discover more bits of the level, that is until you splat the entire level with ink, then dying has no benefits, as it should be. The way that only double jumps  splat ink everywhere is a great choice making levels more difficult and interesting.
- A good difficulty curve, as a good precision platformerer like myself you would not find anything in the first 2 world too difficult and the 3rd world will get challenging, for newer players the game eases in to the difficulty very well making sure that the first 15-20 levels won't be tough, neither will the first boss. The game DOES get difficult and you will die many MANY times in your playthrough(s). Each enemy is brought in at a good time so levels don't feel repetative and then once you know hoe they behave, they get diffucult again.
- Enemies are very predictable and the fact that they leave ink trails just adds to pretty nature of the game. I do have a few issues with the basic enemies as seen below
- The physics is very nice and floaty simular to Super Meat Boy, it feels a bit slippery as you'd expect and suits the game well.
- Fantastic level design, some levels are repeated with extra difficulty and enemies and I can't fault any level!
- It is a great speedrun for people who want to get into speedrunning or for experienced runners, it becomes a test of memory to complete it, very fun!


Mixed:
- Bosses are well done although I do have a few problems, the 2nd boss took me a while to figure out what I needed to do, once I'd done that it wasn't too bad and also the final boss (quite rightfully) alot harder than the others making it an interesting fight, it is hard but once you know the attacks it becomes quite easy to manipulate to your advantage, otherwise the bosses are well made, the first one is a great introduction to how you damage them. All in all well designed!
- When you kill enemies, your sometimes feel like you can't get away from triggers that crush you, this maybe because you didn't hold the other direction soon enough.
- For experienced precision plateformerers, the game can feel a little bit short but with mensions of DLC with more levels AND potential steam workshop support (one of the developers said this may be a possability when I talked to them) it should get even more reasons to play.

Bad:
- Ememies. I have 2 problems with the normal enemies in this game:
1) The fact that you don't get your double jumo back after killing them (this is just personal preferance and is probably a design choice),
2) Going into the side of enemies feels inconsistant whether or not they die, again there may or may not be something I do not understand about this.


Conclusion:
Very well made, solid game with minimal faults, definatly worth playing! I are a few issues but PLEASE don't let that put you off because this game is truely fabulous. It's so different and so interesting that anyone that gets this far through reading this review NEEDS TO PLAY THIS GAME...

reviewText:
For a long portion of last year every time I‚Äôd catch a glimpse of Zack Bell‚Äôs Ink I had to take a moment to pause and check that I wasn‚Äôt in fact looking at a more frantic DAGDROM. Perhaps it‚Äôs due to stumbling upon them both at nearly the same time (Ink may very well have nudged DAGDROM off the front page of itch.io only a week or two after I first played it), each sporting their own squiggly paint-flinging aesthetic, but on the surface I couldn‚Äôt help but find the two games near indistinguishable from one another. Which probably says more to my tendency toward snap judgements than it does to either game in question, as beyond a similar fascination with the messy possibility of flinging paint all over a level Ink and DAGDROM couldn‚Äôt be more dissimilar.

In far more ways that matter Ink actually shares a greater kinship with the brutal platforming classic, Super Meat Boy. You could almost speculate that Ink‚Äôs explosive paint mechanic was inspired directly by Super Meat Boy‚Äôs similar blood splatter effect, but where that served as little more than a macabre monument to your failures Ink turns it into a brilliant platforming meta game, dropping you into levels which are near entirely invisible and requiring you blast paint everywhere to reveal your way through. It‚Äôs a bit like the painting mechanics of the charming and underappreciated de Blob, albeit with fewer analogies to totalitarian governments and more jello squares finding their way through the darkness.

Ink‚Äôs concept really is dead simple in principle, but there is something wonderfully delightful about a game that is entirely about making as big of a mess of a given level as you can by means of so many gooey psychedelic colors. Ink‚Äôs look is minimal in the sense that it‚Äôs made up of little more than the most rudimentary of geometric shapes, but there is a liveliness to it all that is infectiously energetic. The way the little square protagonist jiggles with every move feels like far more than a flat stand-in for an actual character, overflowing with a joyful abundance of energy that is all but demanding you keep moving, always keep moving. Ink is often so understated that it verges upon ambivalence, but the little touches found in the way characters move or the way paint arcs just so give the game an enthusiastic personality, and look impeccable to boot.

What‚Äôs most special about Ink though is how it uses its visual flair in tandem with its level design, intertwining the two to form a mechanical and graphical synergy. Paint is used to reveal hidden platforms, but it also serves as a helping hand when you begin to fail repeatedly, each death causing you to explode in a shower of paint revealing more of the level and making navigating it that much easier. It‚Äôs a small touch but it‚Äôs one of the most clever answers to the problem of static platformer difficulty I‚Äôve seen without eating away at the challenge enough to cause it to feel cheap. Ink is ruthless in its attempts to keep you from completing a level, but it always balances its difficulty by giving you enough room to breathe, to find your way through levels and suss out how best to approach them before murdering your square with wild abandon. I still found myself exhausted and out of breath upon finally making it through to the end, but it‚Äôs a testament to Ink‚Äôs design that it never felt like as if that end was beyond my ability, no matter how many dozens of times I might die to the same bloody turret. Or spiked wall. Or bottomless pit of my existential despair.

It probably helped that I was able to complete Ink in just over a very speedy hour, but this brevity didn‚Äôt come at the price of substance. Ink might be short (by many people‚Äôs judgement, at least), but it feels very full, lasting just long enough to exhaust its clever hook without diluting it with filler. It‚Äôs all remarkably well considered, with even the levels that are near mirror images of one another feeling essential and just as creative as their original counterpart.

Though it might have taken me too long to recognize Ink as its own game, it was a distinction worth making as Zack Bell‚Äôs mess obsessed creation is among the most enjoyable platformers I‚Äôve played in quite some time. It‚Äôs as charming as it is infuriating, but it never dangles the carrot too far out of reach that you lose sight of it completely. Though it is likely hard to lose sight of a metaphorical carrot covered in as many different colors of florescent paint as this one surely is.

reviewText:
INK is a minimalist hardcore platformer where you paint levels as you play, by running and sliding along surfaces, and with the paint splatter of your many deaths. You're not forced to die to succeed though, since the colored enemies also paints the surfaces they touch, and your double-jumps fling sprays of paint on your surroundings, so you are never forced into a leap of faith.

Each regular level has a goal portal you have to get to, but if there are enemies in the level, you first have to get rid of all of them by jumping on them to activate the exit. The most frequent obstacles are large gaps and spikes, but the later levels also have cannons, which shoot target seeking projectiles at you, and they're by far the most difficult hazard to avoid. If you want to collect all of the 20 coins hidden in the game, you're also forced to take some risks, since you won't actually see them until you paint them, so you have to explore each level thoroughly to reveal them.

The controls are responsive, and pulling off long and precise jumps is easy when you get a hang of the game. Landings feel a bit slippery though, and that caused me a fair bit of frustration before I learned to make small jumps directly after touching down to adjust my landings. In the more hectic levels you won't always have time for that luxury though, so it's possible that this is a design choice to force a faster play style. I also never got comfortable with the way you get forced into a wall jump and flung away if you stand too close to a wall while jumping. In contrast to the upwards wall slides of Super Meat Boy, this effect seems much less forgiving.

It took me about four hours to reach the end of the 75 levels, but I struggled with many of them, and the game can likely be finished in much less time by a more skilled player. There are some difficulty leaps marked by the bosses at the end of every 25 levels, but I found the bosses themselves to be easier than many of the levels leading up to them.

The game works well with my wired Xbox 360 controller on Linux, but as always with games like this, I much prefer to use keyboard controls. I haven't experienced any technical issues with the game itself, but unfortunately Steam's screenshot feature doesn't work on Linux. It's a shame since I quite like the look of the multicolored paint covered levels and would have loved to share them with my Steam friends.

If you like a difficult platformer with a unique gimmick that adds both style and challenge, you can't go wrong with INK.

NOTE: This review was originally posted on GamingOnLinux[www.gamingonlinux.com].

reviewText:
This game is a slight breath of fresh air if you've had a hard time finding a new platformer worth playing lately. Making the player become the catalyst that reveals the platforms that are hidden adds a surprisingly non-obtrusive mechanic to the platforming in INK. The very bright contrasting colors your character (Of seemingly white light or something of the sort) shoots out colors across the spectrum when it double jumps, runs along the ground, or meets its early demise.

Dying almost becomes an additional tool to aid you in completeing a level, and for obvious purpose. The soundtrack is very ambient and calming, which complements the early levels of INK, but make no mistake, the difficulty does ramp up in time!

Controls feel tight and reminiscient of Super Meat Boy, I don't feel cheated if I fall to my death because its not typically because of a bugged jump or something of the sort.

All pros aside, there is one con I find that detracts enough that it is worth mentioning. This game seems to be capped at 30 FPS and it shows when the colored ink flies through the air, or when you move your character around. The bright and very contrasting colors can also be a factor if your prone to eye strain from numerous bright/saturated colors.

I would say this game is definitely worth playing, but I truly hope the Devs make it so it runs at 60 FPS, and you can swap out the color pallete of the ink with different palletes, like monochromatic, split complementary, and other color schemes, rather than just super bright colors.

8/10, I will be playing this more and more.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
There's not much to say about this game so I will give a list of pros/cons and then give some thoughts on it.

PROS
+Unique concept that works well
+Looks really nice (sort of... more on this later*)
+Fast-paced gameplay with usually pretty good level design
+Nice amount of options for default controls; anything most people would want to use can be used

CONS
-Capped at 30 frames per second... terrible
-*Game is rendered at a low resolution
-Inconsistent controls; especially in the air
-Hitting corners at a certain angle will kill you for seemingly no reason
-Homing projectiles home in way too accurately and are too difficult to dodge
-Music is lackluster
-Game is very short; 1.5 hours and I'm done already
-No options menu: this means...
-Resolution can not be changed, nor can the game be put into a windowed mode; it is fullscreen by default
-Anything else that usually comes with an options menu cannot be changed

To expand on some of the points;

The inconsistent controls are one of this game's biggest problems; the momentum is very inconsistent. Trying to adjust the momentum of a jump whilst mid-air feels more like luck than anything else; you may completely change direction or you may just slow down. It's unnacceptable.

The homing projectiles can spin a full circle (360 degrees!) if you dodge them and will continue to home in on you,
Need I say more?

I like the concept; it's really unique and works well. It pains me to write a negative review on this game. Unfortunately, the game is poorly built and very short. With all the issues this game has, I can't reccomend it. Even if the developers fixed all of the issues I've listed, I still would not reccomend that you buy this game at full price. Seeing as how the game only lasted me 1.5 hours, I'd pay 4 bucks for it at the very most.

If one of the developers reads what follows this, they will surely be insulted, but it's the truth, and it's the best way to sum up the review:

There are better, free flash games out there. Don't waste your money.

reviewText:
Well well, now here's a surprisingly simple yet fun and hard game.  Platformers aren't really my thing, but this game is a welcomed exception.

I usually don't do reviews but this game does deserve one.  This is probably one of the more challenging platformers I've ever had the pleasure of playing.  And I love a good challenging game.  Makes me think over just what it is that I have to do in order to advance to the next part of the level; how can I make this jump; how is this jump even possible; how do I even get that coin?!
This game forces you to think fast, something I'm not used to, but something I definitely appreciate.  The fast pace of the game only adds to the challenge, because you have to tap your keys just enough to make that landing or risk overshooting it.  Oh man, and the complexity of the jumps you have to make is just well thought out.  Kudos to the developer for putting complexity into simplicity.
The only thing that I am kind of frustrated with is...my tendency to hit the 'A' button when really I want to hit the 'D' button.  Damn me and my weak hand-eye coordination.

But overall, I give this game a 9/10.  Why?  Because sometimes a simple game can be just as good as a game like Skyrim.  Definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for fun and a simple challenge in their gameplay.

reviewText:
This game has a very interesting concept of platforming that has been brought up earlier (before this game was released) but no one really made a full game out of this concept.

The idea of the game is very simple; You complete levels in a rising difficulty. Too bad you can't see the levels. Atleast when you first look at it. The idea is to paint the level so you can see where to stand and where you have to go by double jumping or killing yourself. This way you splatter paint everywhere around you which tags the invisible platforms.

Every level is going to take a few tries since you obviously are going to die alot if you don't know where the platforms are. You even get achievements for dying, so don't be ashamed of just killing yourself in places you haven't painted yet.

The game has 75 levels in total, with 3 bosses at 25, 50 and 75. Before 25 and 50 the levels are somewhat easy and shouldn't be too hard, but when you get to 50-75, you'll start to feel the pain the game is all about. Alot of that good old skill-based platforming with spikes, turrets and stuff like that. But it's gonna ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you off.

And for the completionists out there, you're gonna enjoy this game. A lot. (Check the achievements and you'll see what I mean)

Overall, a very good platforming game, and it's quite cheap too.

reviewText:
INK is a very basic 2D platformer game whose central premise is that the entire level starts out invisible to the player. You play a square ‚Äì some sort of ink sponge? I don‚Äôt really know ‚Äì who can double jump and wall jump. Every time you touch any surface, you put ink on that surface, revealing it. Every time you double jump, you spurt out ink, revealing nearby surfaces. There are also some square enemies which slide around the level, revealing surfaces, and some things which shoot triangles or circles at you, which explode into bursts of ink when they strike surfaces. And if you die, you shoot out a bunch of ink, revealing the area around where you died.

The goal is to navigate through each level without dying, either by touching any of the edges of the screen (including the top and the sides) or by touching an enemy‚Äôs sides or a projectile. If there are enemies in the level, you must stomp on all of them to make the exit open up.

Ink is persistent in levels between deaths, meaning that successive attempts on each level get easier as the level gets increasingly revealed. While this is convenient, it also means that the exploration aspect of the game is lessened. This isn‚Äôt really a bad thing per se, but it means that the mechanic has less of an impact than it might seem at first glance.

Deaths are, thankfully, extremely short, with the square respawning within a second or two at the start of the level. This is very convenient, and is a good feature for a game like this. The game is quite easy at the start, but gets progressively more difficult; it is never TOO hard, though, and always feels fair.

The game is extremely simplistic. The enemies all just slide along the ground, wandering back and forth like square goombas. The projectile things shoot rhythmically. Platforms are platforms. There are some moving platforms later in the game ‚Äì some helpful, some of which try to crush you to death ‚Äì as well as some spiked walls, which are instant death to touch. Some of the levels also have keys, which get rid of ‚Äúlock blocks‚Äù, squares with keyholes on them which are instantly banished when you collect the appropriate key.

There are also 20 little circles with hearts in the middle of them hidden throughout the game; collecting one, then completing the level with it, collects it permanently.

There ae three bosses in the game as well, at levels 25, 50, and 75. Each has their own unique mechanic. None are particularly difficult, and I beat the final boss without dying while fighting it.

All the levels are very short, as is appropriate for a game like this. There are 75 levels in all, though, and I beat the game in 78 minutes ‚Äì and collected 17 of the 20 collectables in that time, without any sort of guide at all. It took me another 5 minutes to collect the last 3 collectibles, giving me a total playtime of 83 minutes, during which not a single Steam trading card dropped.

Some might think that the game being so short is a bad thing, but this is inaccurate; the game is as long as it should be. Frankly, the mechanics were pretty much exhausted by the end of the game, and the central mechanic of revealing the levels as you went through them with ink just didn‚Äôt lend itself to certain sorts of complicated puzzles. And indeed, in many of the later levels, the projectiles constant motion and spattering meant that the level was often largely revealed by the time I went through it anyway, sort of nullifying the central mechanic.

Indeed, in the end, the central mechanic of revealing the levels with ink is really a visual gimmick to make the game look more visually interesting. It succeeds at that; despite the game‚Äôs very basic visuals, it never really felt like it was visually boring in the way of many cheap 2D indie games.

The main problem with this game is that it is simply utterly unexciting. Once you realize that the ink thing is just a visual gimmick, you‚Äôre down to basic 2D platformer gameplay with bog-standard mechanics. I‚Äôve played lots of 2D platformer games which are fundamentally exactly the same as this game, and while this game isn‚Äôt terrible, it is generic and completely unremarkable.

All in all, I can‚Äôt recommend it, but not because it is bad. It is simply thoroughly mediocre. The only thing it has going for it is the ink gimmick, but after a while you stop even noticing it so much, and when you get to the end, you‚Äôre probably going to be left feeling like you did a thing, and that was that.

If you DO get this game for some reason, keep in mind its very short length while purchasing it; if you are looking for something which is going to last you a while, this is not the game for you.

If you already own this game, this is an hour-long 2D platformer with okay mechanics and level design, and is a very quick download; if you‚Äôre really itching for a quick 2D platformer scratch, this isn‚Äôt a terrible choice, though there are lots of better games in the genre. But if you‚Äôre looking for anything remarkable, you‚Äôd best look elsewhere.

reviewText:
(For a tl;dr, read another review that has a tl;dr.)

It's a bit difficult to pin down why it is I don't recommend INK. I like challenging games, I like platformers (provided they are at least somewhat innovative), and I'm always appreciative of cool art styles, especially when they are germane to the gameplay (which this one certainly is!). I think it's the fact that for every good thing I can say about INK, there's some kind of ugly caveat following it.

The paint splattered everywhere in the darkness is beautiful, BUT the game's art is otherwise rather boring. The platforms are just rectangles of varying dimensions (with no colour, as per the game's premise), that move at varying speeds, sometimes with spikes on them. There is never any curve or slope, beynond horizontal and vertical. It's a shame because using this mechanic of revealing platforms with colour should entail a joy of discovery, but it simply isn't there. All you find is rectangle, after rectangle, after rectangle. Even your character and your enemies are simple geometric shapes.

INK is challenging, BUT not always in a satisfying way. Again, I'm struggling to pin down why this is. I think it's to do with the game mechanic all but requiring death as a means of progressing forward, since as you die, ink sprays out to your surroundings to illuminate how you died and how to do better next time. I like this in principle, but it cheapens death until it feels like it has no impact except maybe a slight semi-indifferent annoyance.

The game's concept is neat and original, BUT once the levels are illuminated after many pointless deaths, the game loses all of its originality, and the fact that it's a Super Meat Boy clone becomes painfully obvious. In fact, the painting of walls while wall jumping or dying was clearly inspired by Super Meat Boy. Your character even looks a little like Meat Boy, and the enemies all seem to be based on enemies or hazards found in Super Meat Boy. There are also secret pickups, much like the band-aids in Super Meat Boy (although the fact that they're invisible until your ink illuminates them is pure genius!).

~~~

I definitely think there's something to this idea, but I feel like there needs to be more. I would like to have seen a more interesting art style and level design, maybe with a 3D look? I like the idea of things in the background that get sprayed with ink and objects in levels being more concrete in theme (e.g. the platforms and background could take on an alleyway theme, or a construction site theme, etc). I also wouldn't object to a more open, metroidvania-style world structure, where your previously splattered ink could mark your way.

Enemies could be more varied as well, and fit better into the theme. There could be an enemy that attacks you (rather quickly) if it gets covered in ink (but loses its ink upon death). Maybe, for a bit of puzzle-platforming flavour, there could be enemies that help you solve some kind of puzzle? I respect that this isn't a puzzle-platformer, but again I just feel like there needs to be something else to make this game memorable and something worthy of a recommendation.

Look, I hate to do this to an independant developer. I always admire the innovative spirit, and I hope I've come up with some constructive criticism, but the question posed to me is Do you recommend this game?"

reviewText:
INK is a platformer where you use paint to uncover the level and make your way through it as you would any other platformer. There are several ways to spread paint, such as simply moving, double jumping, defeating enemies and... Dying.

Yep. Dying.

I absolutely adored INK for its very fast-paced gameplay and the whole concept of using paint to find the level. It is a very interestin ceoncept which was well made. Very, well made.

The game starts you off on very simple and easy levels but at a certain point, the difficulty of the levels suddenly shift and it becomes extremely hard to complete even a single level. You may spend possibly 30 seconds on one level, and then the next, you'll be stuck on it for about 15 minutes at the max. It does get a little frustrating, as after just being on a level for about 1 minute or so, the entire level is uncovered and it becomes a simple platformer, with just the colours of the area changing.

This needs to be pointed out, the soundtrack for the game is extremely well made and simply beautiful. It keeps in with the tone of the game but not when you're screaming your lungs out after dying for the 50th time on the same level. Still, lovely soundtrack.

The game is stuck at 30FPS which I honestly did not like very much, but that is just a matter of opinion and what you're used to.

The game is a little short, so be warned. It took me about 2 hours to finish all 75 levels, and that's it. You can go back to collect all the coins, and get 100% completion, but just the minimum of finishing the levels is approximately 2 hours. It does leave me wanting a bit more, but I can say I am very satisfied.

Overall, the concept of using paint to find the level is well made, the levels are good as well (including the rage inducing ones), music is amazing, and, though short, it has left a very strong impression on me. I would easily place it up there with many other great platformers. I highly recommend buying it just for the concept itself.

More mechanics are gradually introduced, often shocking you at first but nearly immediately becoming easy to understand so no tutorials are necessary. The mechanic of revealing the platforms around you is done as well as I'd like it to be done, and as the main gimmick I feel it was a strong point, however....

After the first boss the difficulty increases dramatically. This however is a nice change from the fairly easy preceeding levels. After the second boss, the difficulty changes for the worse, making most levels just a matter of memorizing the exact second to jump, trying to ignore the constant screen shaking from enemies and ink splattering, and trying your hardest to do everything frame perfect. Combined with the inertia and sloppy controls, it makes it more frustrating than fun. Combined with heat seeking missles that are faster than you, it becomes a real chore. The final boss was a good design, however how to damage it seemed inconsistent - what would hurt it one time kills you another with no discernable reason as to why. ---------------------------------------------------------------------

INK is a good game. Not perfect, but it is very fun. :)

PROS
------

- Great clean aesthetic. Reminds me of '140' (not in terms of its music, but it's 'abstract platformer' design).
- Excellent controls. This is a big one. If a game like this didn't control well, that'd be a deal-breaker from the start.
- Pleasant background music.
- Fun boss fights and just a great 'chill and play' vibe. I dig it a lot.

CONS
------

- Lack of rebindable controls. This doesn't bother me much (since I prefer playing on a controller - and the only button you use is 'A' to jump), but I can see how this would be a hindrance to some.
- Lack of an 'Options' menu of any kind. You either play the game or you don't play the game - that's it. Volume, Resolution, Screen Size - none of that can change. This is a bummer because...
- I suffered from horrendous lag/slow-down - especially on the later levels. Maybe there were too many paint particles on the screen at one time. I dunno. The fact is - the game became so slow that it was unplayable. I reached level 74 of 75...so I may stop there. With such a clean, simple aesthetic this shouldn't be a problem.

Granted, I don't have the most powerful computer in the world, but games like 'Shovel Knight', 'Oniken', 'Shantae and the Pirate's Curse' - and virtually every other 2D game I own - play perfectly fine. So, such laggy performance is a bit of a shock. Perhaps this can be addressed in a future update.

- Also, the pacing is a little weird. After introducing a few gameplay mechanics, there's level after level after level where nothing seems to change - and then projectiles are introduced, which was appreciated. Good ideas are here, but I think it would have been better to see more of them. Thus, the game does not play as smoothly as it could. Also, the boss levels seemed too few and far between. Just my opinion. >_<

FINAL THOUGHTS
-------------------
- Overall, it's a really fun game. Except for some technical issues, it really plays quite well. No story or characters to speak of, but great arcade-like platforming action. A great way to spend an afternoon if you ask me. :)

Final Score: 7.5 out of 10
